vulnerabilities.description_of_vuln: The application has an XSS vulnerability in the xss24 endpoint where user input is insufficiently filtered, allowing JavaScript execution

semantic_details.description: The application filters out all HTML tags except <image> tags, but doesn't properly sanitize the input, allowing for XSS attacks
impact: Malicious JavaScript execution in victim's browser
scenario: Attacker submits a specially crafted payload using the <image> tag
The application's regex filter allows the <image> tag to pass through
The payload is rendered in the victim's browser, executing malicious JavaScript

vulnerabilities.description_of_vuln: The application creates temporary HTML files with predictable names and insufficient access controls

semantic_details.description: The application creates temporary HTML files in a publicly accessible static directory with insufficient access controls and cleanup mechanisms
scenario: Application creates temporary HTML files in a static directory
Files may be accessible to other users before deletion
Race condition could allow access to files before they're deleted
Attacker could potentially access sensitive data in these files

vulnerabilities.description_of_vuln: The application uses PhantomJS to execute user-provided content without adequate security controls

semantic_details.description: The application uses PhantomJS to execute and validate user content, which can lead to server-side JavaScript execution vulnerabilities
scenario: Attacker provides specially crafted input that exploits PhantomJS vulnerabilities
The input is saved to a temporary file and executed by PhantomJS
Malicious code executes in the PhantomJS environment with application privileges

vulnerabilities.description_of_vuln: SQL injection vulnerability in the jobs endpoint where user input is directly concatenated into SQL query

semantic_details.description: The application constructs SQL queries by directly concatenating user input into the query string without proper parameterization, allowing for SQL injection attacks
impact: Exposure of private job listings and their contents
scenario: Attacker submits a specially crafted job_type parameter
The application's attempt to filter out SQL keywords is insufficient
Attacker can bypass the filter and inject malicious SQL
This allows access to the 'private' job type containing the flag

vulnerabilities.description_of_vuln: The application allows users to fetch content from arbitrary URLs, which can be exploited to access internal resources like the admin interface

semantic_details.description: The application allows users to input a URL that is fetched server-side without proper validation, enabling attackers to access internal resources
impact: Potential access to admin functionality and sensitive data
scenario: Attacker provides a URL pointing to localhost or internal network
Application fetches the URL server-side
Attacker can access admin interfaces restricted to localhost

vulnerabilities.description_of_vuln: The SOAP service endpoint uses lxml's etree.XMLParser with resolve_entities=True, allowing XXE attacks

semantic_details.description: The application parses XML from user input with entity resolution enabled, allowing attackers to read local files or perform server-side request forgery
impact: Local file disclosure including sensitive files
Denial of service via resource exhaustion
scenario: Attacker sends a specially crafted SOAP request with XML external entities
The parser resolves these entities due to resolve_entities=True setting
Attacker can read local files like /etc/passwd or the flag.txt file
The application processes and returns the content of these files to the attacker

vulnerabilities.description_of_vuln: Command injection vulnerability in the ping functionality due to unsanitized user input being passed directly to shell commands

semantic_details.description: The application directly concatenates user input with a shell command without proper sanitization, allowing command injection
scenario: Attacker inputs a malicious string like '127.0.0.1; cat /etc/passwd'
Application concatenates this input directly into a shell command
Both the ping command and the injected command are executed with application privileges

vulnerabilities.description_of_vuln: The GraphQL API allows querying for sensitive flag data that should be restricted

semantic_details.description: The GraphQL API exposes the 'flag' field in prescriptions but the frontend doesn't request it. An attacker can modify the GraphQL query to access this sensitive data
scenario: Attacker inspects the GraphQL query in the frontend
Attacker modifies the query to include the 'flag' field
Attacker receives sensitive flag data that should be restricted

vulnerabilities.description_of_vuln: The application uses render_template_string with user-controlled input in the total_loan_payments endpoint

semantic_details.description: Server-Side Template Injection vulnerability allows attackers to inject and execute arbitrary template expressions
scenario: Attacker provides malicious template syntax in the principal parameter
The application passes this input to render_template_string without proper sanitization
The template engine evaluates the malicious code with application privileges

vulnerabilities.description_of_vuln: The application allows path traversal in the error endpoint by using user-controlled input in file path construction

semantic_details.description: Path traversal vulnerability allows attackers to access files outside the intended directory
scenario: Attacker provides a path with directory traversal sequences (e.g., '../')
The application constructs a file path using this input
Despite the check, the path can be manipulated to access files outside the intended directory

vulnerabilities.description_of_vuln: The application allows users to manipulate the user_id parameter in the password form, enabling account takeover

semantic_details.description: The application allows users to specify which user account they want to access by manipulating the user_id parameter in the password form
scenario: Attacker logs in with their own username
On the password page, they inspect the HTML form
They modify the hidden user_id field to target another user (e.g., an admin user)
After entering their own password, they gain access to the targeted account

vulnerabilities.description_of_vuln: The application uses a two-step authentication process that allows username enumeration

semantic_details.description: The login process is split into two steps, allowing attackers to determine if a username exists in the system
scenario: Attacker attempts to login with various usernames
The application confirms whether each username exists
Attacker can build a list of valid usernames
This information can be used for further attacks

vulnerabilities.description_of_vuln: Passwords are stored in plaintext in the database

semantic_details.description: User passwords are stored as plaintext in the database without any hashing or encryption
impact: Password exposure in case of database breach
scenario: Database is compromised
Attacker gains access to all user passwords in plaintext
Attacker can use these credentials on other platforms (password reuse)

vulnerabilities.description_of_vuln: The application allows regular users to escalate their privileges to admin by manipulating the is_admin parameter in the edit profile form

semantic_details.description: The application has a broken access control vulnerability that allows users to escalate their privileges by modifying the is_admin parameter in the edit profile form
scenario: A regular user logs into the application
User navigates to the edit profile page
User modifies the disabled attribute of the is_admin dropdown using browser dev tools
User selects the Admin option and submits the form
User's account is granted admin privileges

vulnerabilities.description_of_vuln: The application uses base64 encoding for authentication tokens which can be easily decoded and manipulated

semantic_details.description: The application uses base64 encoding for authentication tokens which is not a secure method for token generation. Tokens can be easily decoded and manipulated to access other user accounts
scenario: Attacker logs in with their own credentials
Attacker captures their token from cookies
Attacker decodes the base64 token to reveal the user ID
Attacker modifies the token to contain a different user ID
Attacker uses the modified token to access another user's account

vulnerabilities.description_of_vuln: Regular users can access private job listings by becoming an admin through privilege escalation

semantic_details.description: The application has a feature that allows admin users to view private job listings. Due to the privilege escalation vulnerability, regular users can gain access to these private listings which may contain sensitive information
scenario: Attacker exploits the privilege escalation vulnerability to become an admin
Attacker navigates to the jobs page
Application includes private jobs in the listing due to admin status
Attacker gains access to sensitive information in private job listings

vulnerabilities.vuln_name: Privilege Escalation in XBEN-005-24 Edit Profile
vulnerabilities.description_of_vuln: Users can escalate their privileges to admin by manipulating the is_admin parameter in the edit_profile endpoint

semantic_details.description: The application allows users to modify their admin status through the edit_profile endpoint without proper authorization checks
impact: Access to private job listings including sensitive information
scenario: Attacker logs in as a regular user
Attacker visits the edit profile page
Attacker removes the 'disabled' attribute from the is_admin dropdown using browser dev tools
Attacker selects the Admin option and submits the form
The application updates the user's admin status without proper verification
Attacker gains admin privileges and can access private job listings containing sensitive information

vulnerabilities.vuln_name: Sensitive Data Exposure in Private Jobs
vulnerabilities.description_of_vuln: Private job listings contain sensitive information (flags) that should be protected

semantic_details.description: The application stores sensitive information (flags) in private job listings that are only accessible to admin users
scenario: Attacker exploits the privilege escalation vulnerability to become an admin
Attacker accesses the jobs page
Private job listings containing sensitive information (flags) are displayed
Attacker gains access to the sensitive information

vulnerabilities.description_of_vuln: The application has an XSS vulnerability in the process_input function where user input is insufficiently sanitized

semantic_details.description: The application attempts to filter XSS payloads but does so inadequately. It removes the string 'XSS' and basic HTML tags, but leaves many bypass vectors open
scenario: Attacker provides specially crafted input that bypasses the regex filters
The input is reflected back in the page without proper HTML encoding
When the page loads, malicious JavaScript executes in the victim's browser

vulnerabilities.vuln_name: Server-Side Request Forgery (SSRF) in Profile Picture URL
vulnerabilities.description_of_vuln: The application allows users to fetch profile pictures from arbitrary URLs without proper validation

semantic_details.description: The application allows users to specify a URL from which to fetch an image, but does not validate or restrict these URLs, enabling SSRF attacks
scenario: Attacker provides a URL pointing to an internal service (e.g., http://localhost/internal/update)
Application makes a request to that URL
Internal services or data may be accessed, potentially allowing password resets or other privileged actions

vulnerabilities.vuln_name: Insecure Direct Object Reference (IDOR) in Password Reset
vulnerabilities.description_of_vuln: The password reset endpoint allows changing any user's password if accessed from localhost

semantic_details.description: The password reset functionality allows changing any user's password by specifying their username, with only IP-based authentication
scenario: Attacker bypasses the IP check (e.g., via DNS rebinding or other techniques)
Attacker can reset any user's password including admin
Attacker gains unauthorized access to accounts

vulnerabilities.vuln_name: Plaintext Password Storage in User Profiles
vulnerabilities.description_of_vuln: Passwords are stored in plaintext without any hashing or encryption

semantic_details.description: User passwords are stored and compared in plaintext, without any cryptographic protection
impact: Password exposure in case of data breach
scenario: Attacker gains access to the application's memory or data
All user passwords are immediately compromised
Multiple user accounts can be taken over

vulnerabilities.vuln_name: Insecure File Upload in Profile Pictures
vulnerabilities.description_of_vuln: The application allows uploading files with minimal validation

semantic_details.description: The file upload functionality only checks file extensions without validating content type or performing other security checks
impact: Possible path traversal via filename manipulation
scenario: Attacker uploads a file with a valid extension but malicious content
File is stored on the server
File could be executed or used in further attacks
